keywords.value: PAHLAVI, HER IMPERIAL HIGHNESS PRINCESS ASHRAF
keywords.name: persons

lead_paragraph: PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Survived by her son Prince Chahram Pahlavi, five grandsons and great-grandchildren. Her Imperial Highness was President of the Women's Organization of Iran, Honorary Vice Chair of Iran's National Committee for World Literacy Program, Vice President of the Imperial Organization for Social Welfare, Head of the Iranian Delegation to the United Nations, Chair of the First United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Tehran in 1968, Chair of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, Honorary President of the Foundation for Iranian Studies, Pioneer in women's rights and was the first woman to appear unveiled in public. As emissary for her brother, she developed tied to many nations of interest to Iran. A skilled diplomat who successfully established full diplomatic relations between Iran and the Peoples Republic of China. In exile she remained active supporting initiatives related to reviving Iran's cultural, literary and artistic heritage. 1/3

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAHLAVI, HER IMPERIAL HIGHNESS PRINCESS ASHRAF

snippet: PAHLAVI--Her Imperial Highness Princess Ashraf, twin sister of His Late Imperial Majesty, Shah of Iran, died peacefully in her home in Europe January 7 at age 96. Survived by her son Prince Chahram Pahlavi, five grandsons and great-grandchildren. Her Imperial Highness was President of the Women's Organization of Iran, Honorary Vice Chair of Iran's National Committee for World Literacy Program, Vice President of the Imperial Organization for Social Welfare, Head of the Iranian Delegation to the United Nations, Chair of the First United Nations Conference on Human Rights in Tehran in 1968, Chair of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, Honorary President of the Foundation for Iranian Studies, Pioneer in women's rights and was the first woman to appear unveiled in public. As emissary for her brother, she developed tied to many nations of interest to Iran. A skilled diplomat who successfully established full diplomatic relations between Iran and the Peoples Republic of China. In exile she remained active supporting initiatives related to reviving Iran's cultural, literary and artistic heritage. 1/3
